translations.translation: OK, I came back to tell you.
You will meet him over there.
Wait a while, soon they will all come past.
Long ago two people went past.
OK, the two of them came here.

sentences.transcription: gari nadyagali gulha yundru yalairri garnaani yanhthadhikagali

translations.translation: Hey when you were looking over there did a man go past?

sentences.transcription: gawa ngathu inha dumparra/ nhanigurru nhungka bagalani

translations.translation: Come, I will show you his track. (Come I will show you / this is his track.)

sentences.transcription: nadya nhanhaguru/ garnaandru wirlidigala barlkaandru nhanha nanduanha

translations.translation: Look at that man leading that horse with a string.

notes: is this an imperative with an optional subject? appears to have bare verb, but verb isn't sentence-initial

sentences.transcription: nhaniyi nugaani/ walya barninyi ngathu nunpalangu

translations.translation: I will not pull that hair.
Yes I will roll that one.
This stone will fall in the water.
This stone will fall down along the steep bank into the water.
This stone will roll into the water.
The two of us will catch this goanna.
Spear this emu with a spear.
Yes, I am already spearing it.

sentences.transcription: gudyu ngathu nhanha nunpalangu dratyalangu nganha

translations.translation: If/when I kick it, (it) may bite me.

sentences.transcription: nadyarra gulha ngathu ingka ngarnidyanha/ ngutyarra ngathu nhinha nguthianha

translations.translation: When I see your father I will give him meat.
OK, I will throw it away.
Already this tree is growing quickly.

notes: what-from/what-at (maybe also apprehensive use of locative?)
log looks like it has an accusative case marker on it

translations.translation: I will go to the doctor I think.
You will go to the doctor, I think.

sentences.transcription: munkaiyigala nganyi gukaani/ nadyarra bari yundru nganha

translations.translation: I am having pains in the head. I think you will see me.
Tomorrow I think I'll have pains.
